00056 const unsigned short CMath::angle_to_sin[90] = 
00057 {
00058        0, 1144, 2287, 3430, 4572, 5712, 6850, 7987, 9121,10252,
00059    11380,12505,13626,14742,15855,16962,18064,19161,20252,21336,
00060    22415,23486,24550,25607,26656,27697,28729,29753,30767,31772,
00061    32768,33754,34729,35693,36647,37590,38521,39441,40348,41243,
00062    42126,42995,43852,44695,45525,46341,47143,47930,48703,49461,
00063    50203,50931,51643,52339,53020,53684,54332,54963,55578,56175,
00064    56756,57319,57865,58393,58903,59396,59870,60326,60764,61183,
00065    61584,61966,62328,62672,62997,63303,63589,63856,64104,64332,
00066    64540,64729,64898,65048,65177,65287,65376,65446,65496,65526,
00067 };

00072 
00073 int CMath::Sin(short angle, int length)
00074 {
00075    int result;
00076 
00077    // normalize to 0..359
00078    if (length < 0) {
00079       length *= -1;
00080       angle += 180;
00081    }
00082    if (360 <= angle) {
00083       do {
00084          angle -= 360;
00085       } while (360 <= angle);
00086       //angle = angle % 360; // correct, but slower on average
00087    } else if (angle < 0) {
00088       do {
00089          angle += 360;
00090       } while (angle < 0);
00091       //angle = (u16)((angle + 33120) % 360); // correct, but slower on average
00092    }
00093 
00094    if (angle < 180) {
00095       if (angle < 90) {
00096          result = (int)(((unsigned int)length * angle_to_sin[angle] + 32768UL) / 65536UL);
00097       } else if (angle == 90) {
00098          result = length;
00099       } else {
00100          result = (int)(((unsigned int)length * angle_to_sin[180 - angle] + 32768UL) / 65536UL);
00101       }
00102    } else {
00103       if (angle < 270) {
00104          result = -(int)(((unsigned int)length * angle_to_sin[angle - 180] + 32768UL) / 65536UL);
00105       } else if (angle == 270) {
00106          result = -length;
00107       } else {
00108          result = -(int)(((unsigned int)length * angle_to_sin[360 - angle] + 32768UL) / 65536UL);
00109       }
00110    }
00111    return result;
00112 }
00113 
00114 int CMath::Cos(short angle, int length)
00115 {
00116    return Sin(angle + 90, length);
00117 }

00120 
00121 unsigned int CMath::Sqrt( unsigned int n )
00122 {
00123    unsigned int lo;
00124    unsigned int hi;
00125 
00126    if (65535U * 65535U <= n)
00127       return 65535;
00128 
00129    if( n <= 65535 )
00130    {
00131       lo = 0;
00132       hi = 256;
00133    }
00134    else
00135    {
00136       lo = 256;
00137       hi = 65535;
00138    }
00139 
00140    do
00141    {
00142       const unsigned int mid = (lo + hi) / 2;
00143 
00144       if( mid * mid <= n )
00145          lo = mid;
00146       else
00147          hi = mid;
00148    }
00149    while( lo + 1 < hi );
00150 
00151    return lo;
00152 }

00154 
00155 void CMath::InterpolateLine(int *x, int *y, int end_x, int end_y, int step_size)
00156 {
00157    short delta_x, delta_y, angle;
00158 
00159    if ( step_size <= 0 || ( *x == end_x && *y == end_y ) ) return;
00160 
00161    delta_x = short(end_x - *x);
00162    delta_y = short(end_y - *y);
00163 
00164    if ( abs(delta_x) > 255 || abs(delta_y) > 255 )
00165       angle    = GetAngle( delta_x/2, delta_y/2 );
00166    else
00167       angle    = GetAngle( delta_x, delta_y );
00168 
00169    if ( *x < end_x )
00170    {
00171       *x += Cos( angle, step_size );
00172       if ( *x > end_x ) *x = end_x;
00173    }
00174    else
00175    { 
00176       *x += Cos( angle, step_size );
00177       if ( *x < end_x ) *x = end_x;
00178    }
00179 
00180    if ( *y < end_y )
00181    {
00182       *y += Sin( angle, step_size );
00183       if ( *y > end_y ) *y = end_y;
00184    }
00185    else
00186    { 
00187       *y += Sin( angle, step_size );
00188       if ( *y < end_y ) *y = end_y;
00189    }
00190    return;
00191 }
00192 
00193 /*
00194         CMath::Get_Angle()
00195 
00196         Given arbitrary x, y, this returns angle in degrees 0..359
00197         (Not 0..360 as old asm version did.)
00198 
00199         E.g. Get_Angle(3,3) returns 45; Get_Angle(-4,0) returns 180
00200 
00201         If passed in (0,0), returns 0; could easily be modified to crash.
00202         (And perhaps should.)
00203 
00204         This has been tested vs the old asm Get_Angle;
00205         it agrees, differing at most by 1 from the old result, and
00206         in all such cases I checked, this one was the more accurate
00207         result (this version rounds rather than truncates).
00208         It was also tested for all x,y from -1000 to 1000 versus atan2 function
00209         and never differed by more than 2 from "true" result (which often
00210         varied a little from my HP calculator...).
00211 
00212         This C actually runs a little faster than the old asm code
00213         (without even turning on compiler optimizations).
00214 
00215         It also accepts ints, not just short ints, to plan for possible future use.
00216         (If very large ints are ever used, some additional checking must be added.)
00217 
00218         Written in standard vanilla C, compiles under Watcom or Borland.
00219 
00220         Most importantly, it gives correct results on inputs where
00221         the old version crashes (e.g. -1, 376), which prompted Russ to
00222         rewrite this in clear C to begin with.
00223 */
00224 
00225 unsigned short CMath::GetAngle(int x, int y)
00226 {
00227    short result = -1;
00228 
00229    if (x == 0) {
00230       if (y < 0) {
00231          result = 270;
00232       } else if (0 < y) {
00233          result = 90;
00234       } else {
00235          result = 0;
00236       }
00237    } else if (y == 0) {
00238       if (x < 0) {
00239          result = 180;
00240       } else {
00241          result = 0;
00242       }
00243    } else {
00244       int correction;
00245 
00246       if (x < 0) {
00247          if (y < 0) {
00248             x = -x;
00249             y = -y;
00250             correction = 180;
00251          } else {
00252             const int old_x = x;
00253             x = y;
00254             y = -old_x;
00255             correction = 90;
00256          }
00257       } else {
00258          if (y < 0) {
00259             const int old_x = x;
00260             x = -y;
00261             y = old_x;
00262             correction = 270;
00263          } else {
00264             correction = 0;
00265          }
00266       }
00267 
00268       //assert(0 < x);
00269       //assert(0 < y);
00270       if (x == y) {
00271          result = 45;
00272       } else {
00273          /*
00274             For y < x, this table takes quotient y * 128 / x
00275             (which will be 0..127)
00276             and tells corresponding angle 0..45
00277          */
00278          static const unsigned char quotient_to_angle[128] = {
00279              0, 0, 1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 4, 4, 4, 5, 5, 6, 6, 7,
00280              7, 8, 8, 8, 9, 9,10,10,11,11,11,12,12,13,13,14,
00281             14,14,15,15,16,16,16,17,17,18,18,18,19,19,20,20,
00282             20,21,21,22,22,22,23,23,24,24,24,25,25,25,26,26,
00283             26,27,27,27,28,28,29,29,29,30,30,30,31,31,31,32,
00284             32,32,32,33,33,33,34,34,34,35,35,35,36,36,36,36,
00285             37,37,37,38,38,38,38,39,39,39,39,40,40,40,40,41,
00286             41,41,41,42,42,42,42,43,43,43,43,44,44,44,44,45,
00287          };
00288 
00289          if (x < y) {
00290             const unsigned int quotient = ((unsigned int)x * 128) / (unsigned int)y;
00291             result = 90 - quotient_to_angle[quotient];
00292          } else {
00293             const unsigned int quotient = ((unsigned int)y * 128) / (unsigned int)x;
00294             result = quotient_to_angle[quotient];
00295          }
00296       }
00297           result = short(result + correction);
00298       if (result == 360) {
00299          result = 0;
00300       }
00301    }
00302    return result;
00303 }

00305 
00306 bool CMath::PointInPoly
00307 (
00308         int const                       xt,
00309         int const                       yt,
00310         int const * const       vertex,
00311         int const                       nvertex
00312 )
00313 {
00314         int xnew,ynew;     
00315         int xold,yold;     
00316         int x1,y1;
00317     int x2,y2;     
00318         int i;     
00319         bool inside=false;     
00320         
00321         if (nvertex < 3) 
00322         {
00323           return(0);     
00324         }     
00325         xold=vertex[(nvertex-1)*2];
00326     yold=vertex[(nvertex-1)*2+1];     
00327         for (i=0 ; i < nvertex ; i++) 
00328         {
00329                 xnew = vertex[i*2];
00330                 ynew = vertex[i*2+1];
00331                 if (xnew > xold) 
00332                 {
00333                         x1=xold;               
00334                         x2=xnew;               
00335                         y1=yold;
00336             y2=ynew;          
00337                 }          
00338                 else 
00339                 {               
00340                         x1=xnew;
00341             x2=xold;               
00342                         y1=ynew;               
00343                         y2=yold;          
00344                 }
00345         if ((xnew < xt) == (xt <= xold)         /* edge "open" at left end */
00346            && ((long)yt-(long)y1)*(long)(x2-x1)
00347             < ((long)y2-(long)y1)*(long)(xt-x1)) 
00348                 {               
00349                         inside=!inside;
00350                 }          
00351                 xold=xnew;          
00352                 yold=ynew;     
00353         }     
00354         return(inside);
00355 }
00356 
00357 RECT CMath::BoundingBox
00358 ( 
00359  const POINT &pt1,
00360  const POINT &pt2,
00361  const POINT &pt3,
00362  const POINT &pt4
00363  )
00364 {
00365         RECT bounding;
00366         bounding.top = min( pt1.y, min( pt2.y, min( pt3.y, pt4.y ) ) );
00367         bounding.bottom = max( pt1.y, max( pt2.y, max( pt3.y, pt4.y ) ) );
00368         bounding.left = min( pt1.x, min( pt2.x, min( pt3.x, pt4.x ) ) );
00369         bounding.right = max( pt1.x, max( pt2.x, max( pt3.x, pt4.x ) ) );
00370         return bounding;
00371 }
00372 
00373 RECT CMath::BoundingBox
00374 (
00375  const POINT *verts,
00376  const unsigned int nverts
00377 )
00378 {
00379         assert (nverts > 0);
00380         return std::for_each(verts, verts + nverts, BoundingBoxFinder<POINT>()).BoundingBox();
00381 }
00382 
00383 float const CMath::GetDistanceBetween(POINT const & pt1, POINT const & pt2)
00384 {
00385         float const xDiff = fabsf(float(pt2.x) - float(pt1.x));
00386         float const yDiff = fabsf(float(pt2.y) - float(pt1.y));
00387         return sqrtf(xDiff * xDiff + yDiff * yDiff);
00388 }
00389 
00390 //
00391 // CMath::PointInPoly - Chapter 9, page 284
00392 //
00393 bool CMath::PointInPoly( Point const &test, const Poly & polygon)
00394 {
00395         Point newPoint, oldPoint;
00396         Point left, right;
00397 
00398         bool inside=false;     
00399 
00400         size_t points = polygon.size();
00401 
00402         // The polygon must at least be a triangle
00403         if (points < 3) 
00404           return false;     
00405 
00406         oldPoint = polygon[points-1];
00407 
00408         for (unsigned int i=0 ; i < points; i++) 
00409         {
00410                 newPoint = polygon[i];
00411                 if (newPoint.x > oldPoint.x) 
00412                 {
00413                         left = oldPoint;               
00414                         right = newPoint;
00415                 }          
00416                 else 
00417                 {               
00418                         left = newPoint;               
00419                         right = oldPoint;
00420                 }
00421 
00422                 // A point exactly on the left side of the polygon
00423                 // will not intersect - as if it were "open"
00424         if ((newPoint.x < test.x) == (test.x <= oldPoint.x)         
00425            && (test.y-left.y) * (right.x-left.x)
00426             < (right.y-left.y) * (test.x-left.x) ) 
00427                 {               
00428                         inside=!inside;
00429                 }
00430 
00431                 oldPoint = newPoint;
00432         }     
00433         return(inside);
00434 }
00435 
00436 
00437 
00438 /* lines_intersect:  AUTHOR: Mukesh Prasad
00439  *
00440  *   This function computes whether two line segments,
00441  *   respectively joining the input points (x1,y1) -- (x2,y2)
00442  *   and the input points (x3,y3) -- (x4,y4) intersect.
00443  *   If the lines intersect, the output variables x, y are
00444  *   set to coordinates of the point of intersection.
00445  *
00446  *   All values are in integers.  The returned value is rounded
00447  *   to the nearest integer point.
00448  *
00449  *   If non-integral grid points are relevant, the function
00450  *   can easily be transformed by substituting floating point
00451  *   calculations instead of integer calculations.
00452  *
00453  *   Entry
00454  *        x1, y1,  x2, y2   Coordinates of endpoints of one segment.
00455  *        x3, y3,  x4, y4   Coordinates of endpoints of other segment.
00456  *
00457  *   Exit
00458  *        x, y              Coordinates of intersection point.
00459  *
00460  *   The value returned by the function is one of:
00461  *
00462  *        DONT_INTERSECT    0
00463  *        DO_INTERSECT      1
00464  *        COLLINEAR         2
00465  *
00466  * Error condititions:
00467  *
00468  *     Depending upon the possible ranges, and particularly on 16-bit
00469  *     computers, care should be taken to protect from overflow.
00470  *
00471  *     In the following code, 'long' values have been used for this
00472  *     purpose, instead of 'int'.
00473  *
00474  * Changes from the original code:
00475  *     
00476  *     Used ATL CPoint classes instead of straight integers (MLM)
00477  */
00478 
00479 
00480 /**************************************************************
00481  *                                                            *
00482  *    NOTE:  The following macro to determine if two numbers  *
00483  *    have the same sign, is for 2's complement number        *
00484  *    representation.  It will need to be modified for other  *
00485  *    number systems.                                         *
00486  *                                                            *
00487  **************************************************************/
00488 
00489 #define SAME_SIGNS( a, b )      \
00490                 (((long) ((unsigned long) a ^ (unsigned long) b)) >= 0 )
00491 
00492 int lines_intersect( 
00493         CPoint one, CPoint two,                           /* First line segment */
00494         CPoint three, CPoint four,                        /* Second line segment */
00495         CPoint &result)
00496 {
00497     long a1, a2, b1, b2, c1, c2; /* Coefficients of line eqns. */
00498     long r1, r2, r3, r4;         /* 'Sign' values */
00499     long denom, offset, num;     /* Intermediate values */
00500 
00501     /* Compute a1, b1, c1, where line joining points 1 and 2
00502      * is "a1 x  +  b1 y  +  c1  =  0".
00503      */
00504 
00505     a1 = two.y - one.y; //y2 - y1;
00506     b1 = one.x - two.x; //x1 - x2;
00507     c1 = two.x * one.y - one.x * two.y; //x2 * y1 - x1 * y2;
00508 
00509     /* Compute r3 and r4.
00510      */
00511 
00512 
00513     r3 = a1 * three.x + b1 * three.y + c1;  //a1 * x3 + b1 * y3 + c1;
00514     r4 = a1 * four.x + b1 * four.y + c1;                        //a1 * x4 + b1 * y4 + c1;
00515 
00516     /* Check signs of r3 and r4.  If both point 3 and point 4 lie on
00517      * same side of line 1, the line segments do not intersect.
00518      */
00519 
00520     if ( r3 != 0 &&
00521          r4 != 0 &&
00522          SAME_SIGNS( r3, r4 ))
00523         return ( DONT_INTERSECT );
00524 
00525     /* Compute a2, b2, c2 */
00526 
00527     a2 = four.y - three.y; //y4 - y3;
00528     b2 = three.x - four.x; //x3 - x4;
00529     c2 = four.x * three.y - three.x * four.y; //x4 * y3 - x3 * y4;
00530 
00531     /* Compute r1 and r2 */
00532 
00533     r1 = a2 * one.x + b2 * one.y + c2; //a2 * x1 + b2 * y1 + c2;
00534     r2 = a2 * two.x + b2 * two.y + c2; //a2 * x2 + b2 * y2 + c2;
00535 
00536     /* Check signs of r1 and r2.  If both point 1 and point 2 lie
00537      * on same side of second line segment, the line segments do
00538      * not intersect.
00539      */
00540 
00541     if ( r1 != 0 &&
00542          r2 != 0 &&
00543          SAME_SIGNS( r1, r2 ))
00544         return ( DONT_INTERSECT );
00545 
00546     /* Line segments intersect: compute intersection point. 
00547      */
00548 
00549     denom = a1 * b2 - a2 * b1;
00550     if ( denom == 0 )
00551         return ( COLLINEAR );
00552     offset = denom < 0 ? - denom / 2 : denom / 2;
00553 
00554     /* The denom/2 is to get rounding instead of truncating.  It
00555      * is added or subtracted to the numerator, depending upon the
00556      * sign of the numerator.
00557      */
00558 
00559     num = b1 * c2 - b2 * c1;
00560     result.x = ( num < 0 ? num - offset : num + offset ) / denom;
00561 
00562     num = a2 * c1 - a1 * c2;
00563     result.y = ( num < 0 ? num - offset : num + offset ) / denom;
00564 
00565     return ( DO_INTERSECT );
00566     } /* lines_intersect */
00567 
00568 /* A main program to test the function.
00569  */
00570 
00571 
00572 bool Intersect(const CRect &rect, const CPoint &center, double const radius)
00573 {
00574         CRect r = rect;
00575         double radiusiusSquared = radius * radius;
00576 
00577         /* Translate coordinates, placing C at the origin. */
00578         r.left -= center.x;  r.bottom -= center.y;
00579         r.right -= center.x;  r.top -= center.y;
00580 
00581         if (r.right < 0)                        /* R to left of circle center */
00582         {
00583                 if (r.bottom < 0)               /* R in lower left corner */
00584                 return ((r.right * r.right + r.bottom * r.bottom) < radiusiusSquared);
00585                 else if (r.top > 0)     /* R in upper left corner */
00586                         return ((r.right * r.right + r.top * r.top) < radiusiusSquared);
00587                 else                                    /* R due West of circle */
00588                         return(abs(r.right) < radius);
00589         }
00590         else if (r.left > 0)    /* R to right of circle center */
00591         {
00592                 if (r.bottom < 0)       /* R in lower right corner */
00593                                 return ((r.left * r.left) < radiusiusSquared);
00594                 else if (r.top > 0)     /* R in upper right corner */
00595                         return ((r.left * r.left + r.top + r.top) < radiusiusSquared);
00596                 else                            /* R due East of circle */
00597                         return (r.left < radius);
00598         }
00599         else                            /* R on circle vertical centerline */
00600         {
00601                 if (r.bottom < 0)       /* R due South of circle */
00602                         return (abs(r.bottom) < radius);
00603                 else if (r.top > 0)     /* R due North of circle */
00604                         return (r.top < radius);
00605                 else                            /* R contains circle centerpoint */
00606                         return(TRUE);
00607         }
00608 }
00609 
00610 
00611 float Interpolate(float normalizedValue, float begin, float end)
00612 {
00613         // first check input values
00614         assert(normalizedValue>=0.0f);
00615         assert(normalizedValue<=1.0f);
00616         assert(end>begin);
00617 
00618         return ( normalizedValue * (end - begin) ) + begin;
00619 }
00620 
00621 
00622 void MapYDeadZone(Vec3 &input, float deadZone)
00623 {
00624         if (deadZone>=1.0f)
00625                 return;
00626 
00627         // The dead zone is assumed to be zero close to the origin
00628         // so we have to interpolate to find the right dead zone for
00629         // our current value of X.
00630         float actualDeadZone = Interpolate(fabs(input.x), 0.0f, deadZone);
00631 
00632         if (input.y < actualDeadZone)
00633         {       
00634                 input.y = 0.0f;
00635                 return;
00636         }
00637 
00638         // Y is outside of the dead zone, but we still need to 
00639         // interpolate it so we don't see any popping.
00640 
00641         // Map Y values [actualDeadZone, 1.0f] to [0.0f, 1.0f]
00642         float normalizedY = (input.y - actualDeadZone) / (1.0 - actualDeadZone);
00643         input.y = normalizedY;
00644 }
